item.title: PRISMS
item.description:
From the NIH website:

The Pediatric Research using Integrated Sensor Monitoring Systems (PRISMS) program was launched in 2015 to develop sensor-based, integrated health monitoring systems for measuring environmental, physiological, and behavioral factors in pediatric epidemiological studies of asthma, and eventually other chronic diseases. The following three arms of the PRISMS Program will be closely aligned to ensure functionality of the overall program.

More information can be found here.

Sample Data Dashboard (Not Live)

item.title: Example Talk
item.description: Embed your slides or video here using shortcodes. Further details can easily be added using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Researcher Receives Honourable Mention, 10th Annual GW SEAS R&D Showcase
item.description:
Quan won an Honorable Mention Prize at the 10th Annual GW SEAS Research and Development Showcase. Congratulations Quan!

2016 GW R&D Showcase Award Winners

item.title: Tricorder Featured on Reuters
item.description: Our work was featured on Reuters Moments of Innovations: ‘Tricorder’ brings diagnosis into the home

item.title: Researcher Wins 9th Annual GW SEAS R&D Showcase
item.description: Allan just won the First Place Prize (tied) at the 9th Annual GW SEAS Research and Development Showcase. Congratulations Allan! You can watch Allan’s presentation below.

item.title: Paper on Handheld Microfluidics Published
item.description:
Our paper on Handheld Microfluidics has been published in Lab on a Chip. One step closer to a medical Tricorder!

Check out the GW Today article on this work.

item.title: Tethered-Bead Immune Sandwich Assay
item.description: Our paper on “Tethered-Bead Immune Sandwich Assay” has been published in Biosensors and Bioelectronics. This work is a collaboration with Dr. Jonathan Silver (NIH/GW) and Dr. Keir Neuman (NIH). Jon’s idea of using a DNA-tethered bead to detect a single immune sandwich complex is a very elegant way to achieve digital, or single molecule, biosensing with minimal equipment. All you need are a low magnification lens and a cellphone camera.

item.title: Nano@GW 2014
item.description: Nano@GW 2014 Workshop on Nanophotonics was held on May 14th in Marvin Center 310.

item.title: Stretchable and Bendable Microsystems
item.description:
Our work on stretchable and bendable microsystems was featured in the GW Research Magazine.

The original paper on soft (i.e. stretchable and bendable) packaging of CMOS electronics with Microfluidics was published in Scientific Reports.

“Flexible packaging of solid-state integrated circuit chips with elastomeric microfluidics”, Sci Rep. 3: 1098, 2013.

item.title: Nano@GW 2013
item.description: Nano@GW 2013 Workshop was held on March 29th in Marvin Center. It was a great success!
